reasoning: The critique targets the post’s “strongest-link” rebuttal (counterargument #7), arguing it doesn’t actually answer the compute-bottleneck objection unless it names a specific compute-light pathway and explains why compute constraints don’t jointly bind across routes. This is a real weakness in that particular move, but it’s only one of several independent counterarguments the position offers (e.g., experiment efficiency, extrapolation limits of CES, long-run substitution, etc.), so centrality is moderate-low. Within the attacked slice, the critique is fairly strong: it correctly notes that ‘multiple routes’ doesn’t rebut a claim that compute is a shared bottleneck unless a route is shown to avoid it. The claims are largely accurate/plausible relative to the text (the post gestures at possibilities rather than demonstrating a concrete compute-light path). The critique is clear, focused, and has little filler.
title: The strongest-link framing doesn't identify a concrete compute-light path to superintelligence
